<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p>Indiana American Water will temporarily discontinue service in downtown Crawfordsville Wednesday night to replace three valves and one fire hydrant.</p><p>The shutdown will begin at 6 p.m. and is expected to last approximately five hours to make the needed repairs to the system.</p><p>A boil water advisory will be issued after water service is restored in the area for 24 hours. </p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":null,"size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/journalreview.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news\/local"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-top-asset"><div class="tncms-region-ads" id="tncms-region-ads-fixed-big-ad-top-asset">
<div id="blox-ad-position-fixed-big-ad-top-asset1">
<script type="text/javascript">TNCMS.AdManager.render({region: 'fixed-big-ad-top-asset', slot: 1, fold: "above"});</script>
</div>
</div>
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>The Indiana Department of Environmental Management requires all public water systems to issue a boil water advisory when a significant drop in pressure occurs in the distribution system.</p><p>IAW recommends residents follow these instructions:</p><p>• Immediately after your normal water pressure is restored, flush your internal plumbing until clear water flows from the water faucets.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><p>• Boil water for one minute prior to consumption.</p><p>• This advisory remains in effect until 24 hours from the time issued unless notified otherwise.</p><p>It is recommended that all water used for drinking, cooking and oral hygiene by brought to a full boil for a minimum of one minute. It is not necessary to boil water for other uses.</p><p>Contact IAW at 1-800-492-8373.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"><div class="tncms-block" id="tncms-block-1477892"></div></div>
</div>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>

<head>
<meta charset="utf-8"/>
<meta content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" name="viewport"/>
<title>UPDATE: Barnegat Officials Advise Residents West Of Parkway To Boil Water After Water Main Break | Barnegat, NJ Patch</title>
<meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
<meta content="Barnegat-Manahawkin, NJ - UPDATE: Barnegat Officials Advise Residents West Of Parkway To Boil Water After Water Main Break" name="description"/>

      UPDATE: Barnegat Officials Advise Residents West Of Parkway To Boil Water After Water Main Break    </h1>
<h2 class="h4"></h2> <div class="clearfix summary-additional">

<div class="content-main-image">
<img alt="UPDATE: Barnegat Officials Advise Residents West Of Parkway To Boil Water After Water Main Break" class="img-responsive center-block" src="https://cdn.patchcdn.com/users/93117/2013/08/T800x600/ea2250ae6d9ede9cf6a77890206e84cb.jpg"/> </div>
<div class="content-body center-block" id="article-wrapper">
<br/>Residents who live west of the Garden State Parkway should boil their water as a precaution after a water main break on West Bay Avenue this afternoon, township officials said.<br/><br/>The water main break occurred west of Heritage Point. Residents should boil water used for cooking and drinking, until the precautionary order is lifted, officials said.<br/><br/>Residents in the Heritage Point and Horizon communities may experience low water pressure until a water main break is repaired, Barnegat Township officials said earlier today.<br/><br/>The Barnegat Water Department is working on repairs. Residents should not experience any interruption of service, officials said.<br/><br/><div id="in-article-boxed-recirc"><div class="text-center air-md"><a category="subscribe" class="btn btn-lg btn-cta-alt pill sans in-article-subscribe l-bold" href="/" trigger="article_button_click">   Subscribe  <span aria-hidden="true" class="fal fa-angle-right fa-lg"></span></a></div></div> </div>

BOIL WATER ORDER ISSUED FOR MT. LAGUNA EL PRADO CAMPGROUND

Printer-friendly version
  • August 2013 Articles
  • Mt. Laguna
  • boil water order
  • E. Coli
  • El Prado Campground

 

 

August 27, 2013 (Mt. Laguna) – The County of San Diego, Department of Environmental Health (DEH) has issued a Boil Water Order and Public Notification for the Mount Laguna El Prado Campground water system located on Sunrise Highway, Mt. Laguna, CA 91948 effective immediately. The water system serves a campground and public restroom.

The drinking water system has tested present for total coliform bacteria and absent for E. coli. Total coliform bacteria can come from soils and other sources in the environment and can indicate a problem with the water supply system. The Boil Water Order was issued to ensure all water used is free from contamination. The Boil Water Order will remain in effect until the distribution system has been disinfected and additional samples confirm the absence of bacteria in the water supply.

New Bedford beaches closed to swimming through Wednesday

Tuesday
Aug 27, 2013 at 12:31 PM Aug 27, 2013 at 12:50 PM

Significant rainfall over the last 24 hours raised the threat of elevated bacteria at beaches along East and West Rodney French Blvd. and inside Fort Taber Park, spurring city officials to close the beaches as a precautionary measure.

NEW BEDFORD -- Three city beaches will be closed to swimming through Wednesday, according to the New Bedford Health Department.

Significant rainfall over the last 24 hours raised the threat of elevated bacteria at beaches along East and West Rodney French Blvd. and inside Fort Taber Park, spurring city officials to close the beaches as a precautionary measure.

Beginning Wednesday morning, the water at these beaches will be tested daily until acceptable water quality levels are obtained, allowing swimming can resume the following day. Further updates regarding openings and closures will be made as water quality results are received.

File photo.
Red worms are common in gardens, but officials say they've only heard of one other infestation in the water supply.
DELAWARE COUNTY, Oklahoma -

One Delaware County town is shutting off its drinking water Tuesday night, hoping a good scrubbing will get rid of creepy crawlies in the town's water tower.

Little red worms are causing big worries about the water in Colcord.

Usually, this time of year is when a water system has issues, usually because of low water supply, or maybe there is an equipment breakdown because of high water usage, but in Colcord, it's because of tiny red worms.

In Colcord, people were stopping by the emergency management office on Highway 116 Tuesday, to pick up jugs of water. The city issued a warning, saying water from Colcord's water system may be unsafe to drink.

"We've had tornadoes come through here and wipe us out and ice storms. We've seemed to have managed," said Frank Gibby, of Emergency Management.

But now it's little red worms causing the worry.

"I head about that and I was like wait, what?" said Colcord resident Quinton Blair.

Colcord's water quality is tested twice a day every day of the year. Employees discovered the tiny red worms in the water supply.

"They are passing through our filters and getting into our distribution lines," said Water Commissioner Cody Gibby.

Not knowing exactly what the worms are, or if they can make you sick, the city told its customers not to drink any of the water until they figured it out.

Colcord schools called off classes for the day, as well.

"We'll get through it. This is a tough little town. We'll get through it," Frank Gibby said.

People, like Quinton Blair, who show proof of where they live, can get donated water from emergency management.

"I mean, better safe than sorry, honestly," Blair said.

Turns out, the state Department of Environmental Quality says, according to the CDC, there aren't any known health effects associated with the worms.

Water Commissioner Cody Gibby said he's told the worms are called blood worms. They're the larvae of gnat-like tiny flies. The best strategy is to flush them out of the system. That's what the town will be doing Tuesday night, which means there will be no water flowing after 9 p.m. They're hoping after flushing the system out and scrubbing down the water tower, the problem should go away.

"Just kind of save on the water usage, so we can use as much water, so we can clean our tanks and our systems and our pumps and our filters," Cody Gibby said.

Anyone with concerns about the worms are encouraged to contact their doctor. Colcord will continue to give out drinking water until the red worms are gone.

Bacteria found in creeks

Monday
Aug 26, 2013 at 1:05 PM Aug 26, 2013 at 1:06 PM

Routine testing of creeks in the Bear Creek basin has found coliform bacteria contamination that makes swimming or wading unsafe, the Rogue Valley Council of Governments reported.

Routine testing of creeks in the Bear Creek basin has found coliform bacteria contamination that makes swimming or wading unsafe, the Rogue Valley Council of Governments reported.

Select creeks are tested and high levels of bacteria are common in late summer when water is low and temperatures are high. Fecal coliform bacteria can come from pets, livestock, wild animals, leaking septic systems and illegal dumping.

Among the creeks tested, Neil, Walker and Ashland creeks, all in the Ashland area; Bear Creek downstream from Talent; Griffin Creek from Medford to the creek's mouth; and Jackson Creek from Central Point to the mouth exceeded state bacteria standards for contact recreation such as swimming or wading.

People should be careful when contacting any waterways and especially avoid ingestion, which may cause illness, and contact with open wounds, which may cause infection. Very young children should be supervised so an adult can make sure they don't swallow water.

Water main repairs lead to boil water advisory

Monday
Aug 26, 2013 at 12:01 AM Aug 26, 2013 at 1:05 PM

Emergency water main repairs have led to low pressure and outages in the Holly Ridge area, according to ONWASA officials.


Emergency water main repairs have led to low pressure and outages in the Holly Ridge area, according to ONWASA officials.



Crews are making emergency repairs to a water main at the intersection of Lloyd Street and Ocean.



Those affected are consumers on Holly Street, Lloyd Street, Camp Davis Road, Jones Street, and on N.C. 50 from U.S. 17 to Jones Street.



Periods of low or no pressure in the distribution system increases the potential for back siphonage and introduction of bacteria into the water system. As a result, ONWASA is warning customers that they should boil all water used for human consumption or use bottled water. It is not necessary to boil water for showering or bathing.



Vigorous boiling for one minute should kill any disease-causing organisms that may be present in the water.

<script type="text/javascript">var _ndnq = _ndnq || []; _ndnq.push(['embed']);</script>
</div>
<p><span>CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- The state Department of Health and Human Resources has issued a boil-water advisory for the Kanawha Falls Public Service District following the loss of water pressure.</span><span>Gauley River Public Service District has also issued a boil-water advisory for the areas of Brownsville, Alta, Dixie, Bentree, Bell Creek, Mount Olive, Belva, Beech Glen, Jodie, Rich Creek, Swiss, Lyon Creek, Peters Creek and Drennen following a water main break.</span><span>Customers should boil their water for at least one full minute prior to use until further notice.</span> <span>West Virginia American Water has lifted a boil-water advisory for about 30 residential customers in the Clark Estates subdivision in Huntington. They have also lifted the boil-water advisory for 50 to 100 customers in the area of 6133 Ohio River Rd. near the intersection of Big Ben Bowen and W.Va. 2 and the four-lane highway.</span></p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"><div class="tncms-block" id="tncms-block-608361">

                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 80;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 80) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 80);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>
</div>
</div></div>
</article>

Home » News » Precautionary Boil Water Advisory Lifted

Precautionary Boil Water Advisory Lifted

 Saturday, August 24, 2013 - 21:50 Updated 4 years ago

HUNTINGTON, W.Va. – West Virginia American Water has lifted a precautionary boil water advisory for approximately 30 residential customers in the Clark Estates subdivision in Huntington following a water main break which West Virginia American Water crews have repaired.

The affected area includes Estate Drive, Scenic Lane, Westwood Drive, Crescent Lane and Bee Tree Drive.  

Results of water quality testing have confirmed that water quality meets drinking water standards. Therefore, there is no further need to boil water prior to consumption.

West Virginia American Water thanks its customers for their patience and cooperation during this event. Customers are encouraged to share this information with other West Virginia American Water customers in the affected area. For more information, contact West Virginia American Water’s customer service center at 1-800-685-8660

Boil Water Advisory In Onslow County Neighborhood

By Carly Swain&nbsp|&nbsp
Posted: Thu 5:27 AM, Aug 29, 2013 &nbsp|&nbsp
Updated: Thu 6:18 AM, Aug 29, 2013

Some Onslow County Water And Sewer Authority customers near Pony Farm Road are being asked to boil their water or invest in bottled water for Thursday.

ONWASA said from 9 a.m. - 4 p.m., crews would be working on Denise Drive to repair a waterline there.

Officials said residents along Denise Drive will experience no to low water pressure during the repair time and there is a risk for bacteria to get into the water during those repairs.

Residents are asked to boil any water used for cleaning, cooking, and consumption Thursday or use bottled water instead.

Bacteria found in Rochester water

By NewsCenter16 Staff&nbsp|&nbsp
Posted: Wed 7:08 PM, Aug 28, 2013

A boil order has been issued for the town of Rochester.

The water department issued the advisory after coliform bacteria was discovered in two of the five water samples they collected.

Officials are increasing the chlorine levels to try to resolve the problem. But until then, all cooking and drinking water should be brought to a complete boil for five minutes before using it.

Residents are also being asked to conserve water, and only use what is necessary for household and personal needs.

Further testing was done to see if any other bacteria of greater concern were present.

Nothing was found in that test.

Roberts under boil order

Wed, 08/28/2013 - 4:14pm | Will Brumleve
ROBERTS — A boil order remained in effect late Wednesday afternoon in Roberts, after workers replacing water mains accidentally cut a water line in an alley, prompting the village to shut down its water tower temporarily.
 
The water-main break occurred late Wednesday morning in the west end of the alley between Green and Weldon streets, Village Board President Rick Flessner said. 
Water service has been restored to all residents, but the boil order will not be lifted until after samples are tested.
 
Until then, customers should use boiled or bottled water for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth, washing dishes and food preparation until further notice. That will kill any bacteria or other organisms that might be present in the water.

To properly boil water, bring it to a boil, let it boil for one minute, then let it cool before using.

UPDATE: 2:20 p.m.

Repairs have been completed on an eight-inch Pennsylvania American Water main that broke along Allan Road in Hanover Township and service was restored to all customers.

A boil advisory remains in effect until further notice as a precaution, according to Pennsylvania American Water.

The boil water advisory water advisory applies to customers on Allan Road, Hanover Township; Northampton Street, Laurel Run; and Casey Street, Route 309 between Blackman and Northampton, Johnson, Chase, Walnut, Reservoir, Centre, Semour, Jean, Keating, Walnut, Spruce, Shannon, Metcalf, Lehigh, Slattery and Railroad streets, Evans Lane, Leslie Lane, Marcy Lane, Lyon Lane and Darby Lane, Spencer, Pulaski, Francis, Almond, Augusta and Anderson streets in Wilkes-Barre Township.
Pennsylvania American Water advises residents to bring all water to a boil, let it boil for one minute and cool before using or use bottled water. Residents should use boil or bottled water for drinking, making ice, washing dishes, brushing teeth and food preparation until further notice.

--------------------

Pennsylvania American Water issued a precautionary boil water advisory this morning for customers in parts of Wilkes-Barre Township, Laurel Run and Hanover Township.

A broken eight-inch water main along Allen Street caused low water levels in a storage tank serving the area. Customers might experience no water service or low pressure. Repairs are expected to be completed later this afternoon. About 500 customers are affected.

Pennsylvania American Water experienced a loss in “positive water pressure” on Wednesday due to the water main break, according to a press release from the company.

A loss of positive water pressure is a signal of conditions that could allow contamination to enter the distribution system. As a result, there is an increased chance that the water might contain disease-causing organisms.

The boil water advisory applies to customers on Allan Road, Hanover Township; Northampton Street, Laurel Run; and Casey Street, Route 309 between Blackman and Northampton streets, Johnson, Chase, Walnut, Reservoir, Centre, Semour, Jean, Keating, Walnut, Spruce, Shannon, Metcalf, Lehigh, Slattery and Railroad streets, Evans Lane, Leslie Lane, Marcy Lane, Lyon Lane and Darby Lane, Spencer, Pulaski, Francis, Almond, Augusta and Anderson streets in Wilkes-Barre Township.

Pennsylvania American Water advises residents to bring all water to a boil, let it boil for one minute and cool before using or use bottled water. Residents should use boil or bottled water for drinking, making ice, washing dishes, brushing teeth and food preparation until further notice.

<h5 class="news-title">Tupper Lake issues boil water advisory </h5>
<div class="news-date">
          Wednesday, August 28, 2013 - 4:50 pm           </div>
<div class="content">
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>TUPPER LAKE -- The Village of Tupper Lake has issued a boil water order following a breakdown in the village’s chlorine disinfection treatment.</p>
<p>Residents have been instructed to boil all water from the village water supply used for drinking and cooking.</p>
<p></p><div class="ad-container inner-page-ad-container "><div data-ad-unit-path="/1045456/300x250Innoppl-testing" data-glade="" height="250" width="300"></div>
<script async="async" src="https://securepubads.g.doubleclick.net/static/glade.js"></script></div>“Bring all water to a boil in a clean container, let it boil for one minute, and let it cool before using, use bottle water certified by NYSDOH, or use water from a public water system approved by NYSDOH,” said Jules W. Callaghan, district director, who signed the order.
<p>Boiled water should be used for drinking, ice, washing dishes, brushing teeth, and food preparation until the order is lifted, Callaghan said.</p>
<p>Residents will be notified when the advisory is lifted. The order shall be lifted after two consecutive daily samples with no bacteriological contamination.</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div>
</div>

Local News

Boil-water advisory issued for Henderson

Posted August 28, 2013

Get a new code
You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters

Henderson, N.C. — The City of Henderson is advising some residents to boil water following a pipe break Wednesday.

Officials said customers may experience periods of low or no water pressure as crews work to repair the break to a 10-inch line on Beckford Drive. The low pressure increases the potential for harmful bacteria to enter the water distribution system.

Customers from Beckford Drive to Luluas Landing are advised to boil water vigorously for a full minute before using for drinking, eating, food preparation, washing dishes or brushing teeth.

Officials said the advisory will be rescinded when sample water tests are completed to ensure bacteria levels are safe.

Boil water order lifted in Madison County

MADISON COUNTY, MO (KFVS) -

A boil water order has been lifted for parts of Madison County, Missouri that was due to a water main break.

According to Madison Co. Public Water Supply District #1, the order was for areas beginning at Highway H and south on Highway 67 through Cherokee Pass. It included all connecting state and county roads.

Water line break prompts advisory to boil water

Wednesday
Aug 28, 2013 at 12:01 AM Aug 28, 2013 at 9:39 AM

A large water line break has prompted the city to issue a water system pressure advisory, meaning all residents and businesses in the affected area should boil their drinking water.

Havelock News


A large water line break has prompted the city to issue a water system pressure advisory, meaning all residents and businesses in the affected area should boil their drinking water.



The advisory impacts areas west of Jaycee Street, which is next to Havelock City Park, and includes the Woodhaven and Belltown areas, according to a release from the city. It does not affect Cherry Point.



The advisory will remain in effect until testing samples of the water are returned from the state, which normally takes about 24 hours.



The water line break occurred overnight on Jaycee Street and caused low pressure and water outages throughout the western part of the city. Havelock temporarily switched to Craven County’s system as the line was repaired and flushed, according to the release. The break in the water line caused a lost of about 240,000 gallons of water. 



The advisory also affects several schools in the area, including Havelock Elementary, Graham A. Barden Elementary, Gurganus Elementary, Arthur W. Edwards Elementary and Tucker Creek Middle School. Those schools remain open to students and teachers.



Havelock has notified the Craven County Health Department as well as the nutrition coordinator for the school system.



Periods of low water pressure increases the chance of back siphonage, which could introduce bacteria into the system. As such, the state requires water to be tested after a pressure loss, and the recommendation is made to boil water.



Residents in the affected areas should boil water used for drinking, cooking, brushing teeth, making ice and washing hands for at least one minute, or use bottled water for such purposes instead. Pregnant women and those with infants of up to six months should use an alternate source of water, according to the release.



In the meantime, residents are urged to conserve water as much as possible.
